title.narrative: Second Amendment on Decision of Contribution

description.narrative: Under Component 1 During the first half of 2018 focus was directed towards analysis of capacity at district and national level to generate evidence, support to national surveys critical for resilience, as well as generation of resilience thematic case studies and technical notes. Implementation of capacity building activities was informed by the gaps identified during the capacity assessments under taken in November of 2016 and 2017 for first call and second call consortia. Key achievements during the period under review include ? Impact Evaluations: Baseline impact evaluation was conducted for five sampled projects under ZRBF namely ECRIMS, MELANA, PROGRESS, SIZIMELE and ZVA with data collection processes completed in mid-February 2018. Validation of baseline results was conducted in May 2018, ? Capacity building & Learning: During the reporting period, the following are key achievements:o In June 2018 Open Data Kit Level 2 advanced training was conducted for 30 government officials to further improve skills for data capturing during national surveys,o The 4th ZRBF Biannual Review and Lessons Learnt Workshop was successfully held in Harare from the 12th to the 14th of June 2018. The workshop was held under the theme, “Emerging Good Practices for Resilience Building”. The objectives were to share of good practices and discussion on how these can further be enhanced to contribute towards resilience building and identify critical gaps in current practices that need to be addressed during implementation of various activities. Over 90 delegates participated from all provinces and districts of ZRBF implementation were represented.o Commensurate with improving data capturing and analysis skills, second level SPSS training was also delivered to 50 MLARR officials in June 2018 for improved data entry, cleaning and analysis of the crop and livestock assessments,o On the 26th of March, MLARR and the ZRBF PMU facilitated a workshop on the validation of Irrigation Inventory and its implications on ZRBF programming,o The ZRBF PMU facilitated a district-to-district peer learning visit to Binga with 17 participants including government officials and Sizimele consortium members from Matobo and Insiza. The visit focused on local level planning for resilience building, good practices for artificial insemination, evidence generation capacities within the government departments and high frequency monitoring system functionality,o In support of evidence generation, ZRBF PMU handed over 8 high performance computers, 140 mini desktop computers, 70 GPS machines and 9 pH meters at national, provincial and district level. ? Performance Monitoring: The ZRBF PMU together with MLARR conducted performance monitoring visits to 6 districts namely Binga, Kariba, Mutoko, Zvishavane, Bubi and Matobo. In addition, ZRBF PMU facilitated and participated in Steering Committee biannual monitoring visit to Mwenezi and Chiredzi districts, ? The Resilience Measurement Technical Working Group inception and planning meeting was held in June 2018 with participation of ZRBF PMU and chaired by Food and Nutrition Council, ? Technical notes, support and platforms: With these regards, the technical note on Barriers to Small Grains Value Chains in Zimbabwe was published and disseminated to a wider audience. Furthermore, ZRBF supported the data verification exercise for the First Round of the Crop and Livestock Assessment. A combined report for the First and Second Round Crop and Livestock Assessments for the 2017/18 season was released by MLARR on the 9th of May 2018. MLARR and the ZRBF PMU undertook High Frequency Monitoring System sensitization mission to Mutoko, Mudzi, Mberengwa and Zvishavane. The main outcome of these sensitisation meetings was the commencement of data collection by the respective districts. Under component 2 During the reporting period, ZRBF consortia partners continued to implement planned activities. ? Disaster Risk Management (DRM) implementation and strengthening of DRM structures: With regards to DRM, the key planned activities were monitoring of DRM implementation (for 2016 consortia partners) and strengthening of DRM structures (for the 2017 consortia partners). Fifty nine out of eighty-four at risk communities (wards) (70.2%) had a disaster risk reduction (DRR) and/or integrated disaster reduction and adaptation in their strategy or action plan by the end of the reporting period. Consortia partners therefore continued to support the implementation of DRM plans. Communities have taken the lead and embarked on community led initiatives which has strengthened their ability to respond to emergencies. Continued support of these community led initiatives will see communities bouncing back better from shocks and stresses in a sustainable manner. ? High Frequency Monitoring (HFM): During the reporting period, the project teams and extension officers continued to track the HFM indicators. The data continued to be used for adaptive programming and the dissemination of advisories continued throughout the reporting period. ? Private Sector Engagement/Market Linkages and Financial Inclusion: ZRBF has noted a marked improvement in the number of private sector companies now collaborating with consortia partners although this still has to translate to tangible benefits to the project participants. In addition, some relationships are still fragile, characterized by suspicion and mistrust, thus pointing to a need to invest time in relationship building in addition to farmer training. There is still very little participation of the financial services sector. However, consortia partners are commended for bringing insurance companies on board. Efforts continue to be made to integrate ZRBF activities with other development partners operating in the districts. ? HEALTH/ WASH interventions: The ZRBF funded projects continue to collaborate with a wide range of stakeholders in delivery of HEALTH/ WASH interventions. In total, the ZRBF projects recorded 9 000 out of the planned 10573 (90%) households with access to safe drinking water and basic sanitation during the reporting period. ? Agricultural production and productivity: During the reporting period, the ZRBF through its seven consortia partners trained about 58 038 project participants out of a planned 58 881 (93.5%). Several training strategies were used, including classroom training, farmer field schools, demonstrations, visits to processing facilities and look and learn visits. Trainings focused on different thematic areas such as agronomy for various crops, climate smart agriculture, animal husbandry, fodder preservation, etc. ? Productive Infrastructure: Progress has been made in completion of infrastructure projects, 82 out of the planned 95 functional productive infrastructures were set up through ZRBF support. To improve quality and sustainability, ZRBF is in the process of engaging engineers to assist with quality assurance for infrastructure projects funded under ZRBF. ? Community safety nets: All ZRBF funded projects are promoting (Village Savings and Lending Associations (VSALs) which remain strong foundations for resilience building in the current economic context in rural areas. In addition, they provide financial services at a micro level. Funding of enterprises; food security, insurance and social capital are built within the VSAL methodology. Layering commodity groups on VSAL groups allows community members to take full ownership of activities and mature quickly as they use the already established group governance structures to their advantage in dealing with group dynamics. ? Enhanced Livelihoods: Entrepreneurship development is being promoted across consortia. The ZRBF funded projects continue with initiatives aimed at building an enabling environment as well as paying attention to cross cutting issues such as gender, child protection, HIV/AIDS, nutrition, and environment. ? Project participants registration & reach: The ZRBF PMU has organized technical working session to assist consortia with their databases and beneficiary registration, paying attention to layering, sequencing and integration of interventions as some consortia were struggling with these concepts. ? Technical assistance: The ZRBF PMU organized one on one meetings with consortia partners to address identified gaps, including: data quality assurance, infrastructure projects, private sector engagement, value for money, beneficiary registration matrix, and layering and sequencing of interventions. In addition, joint quarterly review meetings facilitated by the ZRBF PMU were designed to provide a platform for peer to peer learning. The review meetings included field visits and created opportunities for collaboration and sharing of experiences. Under component 3 ? Generating and utilization of high frequency monitoring system: Seventeen districts consistently reported on the 17 indicators for High Frequency Monitoring System except for Umguza which did not submit data in March. ? Crisis modifier mechanism: In March the crisis modifier was activated for Mwenezi, Chiredzi, Umzingwane, Umguza, Bubi, Nkayi, Kariba, Binga and Mbire. ECRAS, MELANA and ZVA consortia were invited to apply for funding from the crisis modifier mechanism to implement early action related activities. The Consortia Partners from BRACT, ECRIMS, PROGRESS and SIZIMELE, being in their first year of implementation, were advised on how to apply adaptive management to add and deprioritise activities in response to HFM system findings. More specific results include: •Problem Tree Analysis: To map the drivers, root causes and effects of decline in wellbeing outcomes to determine leverage points for domain change. •Correlation Analysis: To understand better the cross relationship between exposure to hazards, poverty, food insecurity and stunting. •Solution Tree Analysis: to determine the pathways through which resilience can be built: Resilience Through What? Including Gender, climate change and livelihoods analysis developed. •Theory of Change Developed: to articulate HOW and WHY the interventions will lead to the desired change. •Visibility and Communication strategy developed. •Capacity Building support being rolled out at national, province and district levels. •Analytical products: Multi Hazard maps; ENSO ANALYSIS for Zimbabwe; Barriers to small grains analysis; up-coming solutions; gender, climate chance and livelihoods analysis. •Data generation and analytics: 5 Databases developed and implemented in MLARR for improved quality and timeliness of data; MLARR central, provice and district level staff trained in ODK and SPSS; equipment for improved data management at all administrative levels. •Support to national surveys: •4 Zimvac process supported, since 2017 with inclusion of resilience components in the exercise – recently recognised at SADC level as best practise. •PICES process currently support with inclusion of resilience analysis. •Crop& livestock assessments supported. •National irrigation inventory supported with 5 provinces. •Resilience measurement and indicator guides. •14 High frequency monitoring bulletins. •Web-site, social media platforms. Absorptive Capacity Scenario planning for development of ward level resilience plans. Multi-Hazard Risk Analysis - Household Livelihood Security Assessment (HLSA) and Risk analysis for disaster risk management. Disaster Risk Management structures. Strengthen response capacity and early warning systems. Community fabric and safety nets i.e. communal seed banks, granaries, cash savings. Adaptive Capacity Improved crop, livestock and agroforestry production (Crop-livestock systems,) Creating Income (on farm & off-farm) generating opportunities Small scale productive infrastructure developments Improving community health and nutrition Markets and value chain development Transformative Capacity Improved social, agriculture and water service delivery addressing poverty and building resilience Integrate seasonal advisories with service provider outreach strategies and dissemination using mobile messaging platforms Develop and roll out a community scorecard for improved service delivery Communities engage duty bearers on provision of services •1,053,652 men and woman have benefited from July 2016 to July 2018. • 213 at risk wards with a disaster risk reduction and/or integrated disaster reduction and adaptation in their strategy. • 263 wards with disaster early warning and response (EWR) systems working effectively. •15262 households with access to safe drinking water and basic sanitation supported by ZRBF. •780 functional productive infrastructures developed. •23.6 % women or youth represented in decision making structures at ward and district levels in ZRBF project areas. •184 Agro-dealers capacitated to provide community based revolving supplies and market linkages to smallholder farmers. •2260 farmers participating in value addition of Non- Timber Forest Products (NTFPs). •27.5% of households adopting climate smart agricultural production technologies in year 1. •354 ISALS supported.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

By 2023 policies, strategies, plans, programmes and practices at national and sub-national levels taking on findings of SUMERNET's joint action and research which consider human rights, conflict sensitivity, gender inclusivity and poverty reduction .

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Stockholm Environment Institutes Asien-kontor (SEI Asien) har på uppdrag av det regionala Sustainable Mekong Research Network (SUMERNET) inkommit med en ansökan till ambassaden för fortsatt stöd i fem år till SUMERNETs nästa fas, kallad SUMERNET 4 All. Programmet kommer under nästa tioårsperiod att fokusera sitt arbete på det strategiska målet "Minska vattenosäkerheten för alla, särskilt fattiga, marginaliserade och socialt utsatta grupper av kvinnor och män i Mekongregionen". För den initiala femårsperioden, från 2018 till 2023, är det ansökta beloppet från Sverige 60 miljoner kronor. Forskningsprogrammet kommer att genomföras i Sydostasien / Mekong-regionen (Myanmar, Thailand, Kambodja, Laos, Vietnam och två provinser i Kina)
Insatsen syftar till att bidra till en hållbar utveckling i Mekongregionen genom att stärka kunskapsbaserade politiska processer och överbrygga avståndet mellan vetenskap och politik. SUMERNET åstadkommer detta genom att välja forskningsfrågor som är direkt relevanta för aktuella politiska debatter, engagera beslutsfattare i alla aspekter av sin verksamhet och bygga kapacitet för hållbar utveckling genom mentorstöd, workshops och annan verksamhet. SUMERNET 4 All kommer att fokusera sina ansträngningar på tre specifika forskningstema inklusive (1) tillgång till vatten, rättigheter och fördelning under vattenbrist, (2) styrning och hantering av översvämningskatastrofer och (3) gränsöverskridande vattensystem. SUMERNET betonar också samarbete, nätverkande och kunskapsdelning, samt samarbete mellan aktörer i olika länder genom projekt och evenemang och syftar därmed till att stärka forskning och politiskt engagemang i hela regionen.
Insatsens totala budget är 60 miljoner kronor. Cirka 28 miljoner kronor kommer att användas till forskningsverksamhet, cirka 15 miljoner kronor till flerpartssamverkan och ca 6 miljoner kronor till kommunikation och dissemination av resultat.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Stockholm Environment Institute’s Asia Centre (SEI Asia) has on behalf of the regional Sustainable Mekong Research Network (SUMERNET) submitted a proposal to the Embassy for continued support for five years to SUMERNET’s next phase, called SUMERNET 4 All. The program will over a ten-year period focus its efforts on the strategic goal “Reducing water insecurities for all in particular for the poor, marginalized and socially vulnerable groups of women and men in the Mekong Region’’. For the initial five-year period, from 2018 to 2023, the amount requested from Sweden is 60 million SEK. The research program will be carried out in South East Asia/Mekong Region (Myanmar, Thailand, Cambodia, Laos, Vietnam and two provinces in China)
The intervention aims to contribute to sustainable development in the Mekong Region by strengthening knowledge-based policy processes and a key aspect of SUMERNET’s work is to bridge science and policy. SUMERNET achieves this by choosing research questions that are directly relevant to current policy debates, engaging decision-makers in all aspects of their activities, and building capacity for sustainable development through mentoring support, workshops and other activities. SUMERNET 4 All will focus its effort on three specific research themes including (1) water access, rights & allocation in times of scarcity, (2) governance and management of flood disaster risks and (3) transboundary interactions with water systems. SUMERNET also emphasises collaboration, networking and knowledge-sharing, connecting partners in different countries through projects and events thereby aiming at continually strengthening research and policy engagement across the region.
The intervention’s total budget is 60 million SEK out of wich approximately 28 MSEK will be used for research activities, approximately 15 MSEK to multistakeholder activities and approximately 6 MESK will be used for communications and outreach.

17.6 - Enhance North-South, South-South and triangular regional and international cooperation on and access to science, technology and innovation and enhance knowledge-sharing on mutually agreed terms, including through improved coordination among existing mechanisms, in particular at the United Nations level, and through a global technology facilitation mechanism.

17.6 - Stärka nord–syd-samarbetet, syd–syd-samarbetet och det regionala och internationella trepartssamarbetet kring och tillgången till vetenskap, teknik och innovation samt öka kunskapsutbytet på gemensamt överenskomna villkor, inklusive genom förbättrad samordning mellan befintliga mekanismer, i synnerhet på FN-nivå, och genom en global mekanism för teknikfrämjande.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.

6.3 - By 2030, improve water quality by reducing pollution, eliminating dumping and minimizing release of hazardous chemicals and materials, halving the proportion of untreated wastewater and substantially increasing recycling and safe reuse globally.

6.3 - Till 2030 förbättra vattenkvaliteten genom att minska föroreningar, stoppa dumpning och minimera utsläpp av farliga kemikalier och material, halvera andelen obehandlat avloppsvatten och väsentligt öka återvinningen och en säker återanvändning globalt.

6.4 - By 2030, substantially increase water-use efficiency across all sectors and ensure sustainable withdrawals and supply of freshwater to address water scarcity and substantially reduce the number of people suffering from water scarcity.

6.4 - Till 2030 väsentligt effektivisera vattenanvändningen inom alla sektorer samt säkerställa hållbara uttag och en hållbar försörjning med sötvatten för att angripa vattenbristen och väsentligt minska det antal människor som lider av vattenbrist.
6.5 - By 2030, implement integrated water resources management at all levels, including through transboundary cooperation as appropriate.
6.5 - Senast 2030 genomföra en integrerad förvaltning av vattenresurser på alla nivåer, när så är lämpligt genom gränsöverskridande samarbete.

description.narrative: As of November 2020 the SUMERNET4ALL has been operating for slightly more than 2 years. SUMERNET4ALL is the fourth agreement between Sida and the Sustainable Mekong Research Network hosted by the Stockholm Environmet Institute in Asia. SUMERNET is an initiative for research and policy engagement bringing together research partners working on sustainable development in the countries of the Mekong Region: Cambodia, Lao PDR, Myanmar, Thailand and Vietnam. China is also included in SUMERNET4ALL, however the participation of Chinese researchers in research activities is dependent upon them securing their own research funding. This conclusion on performance covers the period from June 2019 until November 2020. The covid-19 has significant consequences for SUMERNET4ALL. The first case of covid-19 outside China was detected in Thailand in early January 2020, and by late March most countries in the region had imposed strict travel restrictions to limit the spread of the virus. As of November 2020 most international travel is restricted in the region, and in some countries (e.g. Myanmar) there are restrictions on domestic movement and activities. SUMERNET4ALL was originally designed to be dependent upon mobility of researchers and stakeholders to move across national borders in order to attend meeting and trainings, and to carry-out transboundary research projects. As such, the covid-19 has had a major impact on the network and its activities. Despite the challenges associated with the covid-19 pandemic, SUMERNET4ALL has shown a strong capacity to adapt to the new situation, not least through a shift to online video-conferencing and other Internet communication and collaboration tools. The network has also worked together with researchers in the region to reflect upon new challenges and opportunities for research that are posed by the covid-19 pandemic, and to share the lessons learned (see https://www.sumernet.org/story/5-tips-for-success-in-delivering-research-projects-during-covid). These efforts are themselves important results. The challenges and uncertainties associated with the covid-19 pandemic have also created some unexpected delays in the planned activities. For example, field visits by SUMERNET Advisors and Secretariat staff to follow-up and support ongoing projects have been delayed due to travel restrictions. Likewise, the shift from in-person to on-line activities has caused some delays. Further examples of results achieved by SUMERNET4ALL during the period under review include: - Twelve collaborative research grants have been competetively awarded to multi-country/transboundry research projects. Four projects address water access, rights and allocation in times of scarcity. Six projects address governance and management of flood disaster risks, and two projects address transboundary interactions with water systems, including projects measuring the impact of atmospheric pollution deposition on water quality and its influence on community water use. All twelve projects integrate gender into the research, and minority groups' access to water resources. - One research grant was competetively awarded to collaborative research across five countries for a groundwater integrated regional assessment. - SUMERNET has designed and implemented an ethical review process for research projects that receive funding. Thus far, 13 projects have been successfully reviewed. - One research grant was competetively awarded in a special call for a collaborative research project on water insecurities during the covid-19 pandemic. - SUMERNET has seen an improvement in the rate of participation of its members in the elections of steering committee members. - A newly designed website (www.sumernet.org) was launched that includes new material such as interviews, journalistic stories, podcasts, short films, and summaries of network activities. - SUMERNET4ALL has made rapid progress towards meeting or exceeding its target indicators. Amongst these are included the proportion of young researchers involved in SUMERNET projects (target 35%, achieved 49%), the proportion of research projects and joint actions which engage with women/gender organizations as the researchers or boundary partners or target beneficiaries (target 35%, achieved 50%), and the proportion of research projects which address environmental rights in their key research questions (target 15%, achieved 60%) (see 2019 Annual Narrative Report for more information).
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: World Bank Trust Fund Cash Transfers

description.narrative: Objective, outcomes and outputs of the intervention The Multi-Donor Trust Fund (MDTF) will expand and further strengthen the country’s social protection programmes and instruments. Outcome 1:By 2021, increased social protection coverage per capita in the poorest provinces Output 1: By 2021, at least 176.500 poor households in the poorest provinces benefit from social protection programs Outcome 2:Improved quality of service delivery for the payments of cash transfers Output 2.1: Increased share of payments delivered by private service providers Output 2.2:e-INAS gradually being used for the registration and management of SP beneficiaries Between 14 000 and 114 000 households (families) will be reached byt the program as beneficiaries. The numbers may radically increase during 2019 as there are plans for a rapid response to the cyclone hit areas.

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Stöd under 2019-2022 med totalt 75 miljoner SEK till utbyggnad av nationella sociala kontantstöd via Världsbankens Multi Donor Trust Fund, med fokus på att registrera fler förmånstagare, öka bidragsbeloppen (socialbidrag, barnbidrag, beredskapsarbete m.m.) samt stärka kapaciteten på socialförsäkringsmyndigheten INAS. Total budget för programmet är ca 180 miljoner SEK och andra givare är Storbritannien och Nederländerna. Det svenska bidraget uppgår till ca 41 procent an total budget. Fonden är aktiv sedan slutet av 2018.
Insatsen förväntas bidra till effektiva och transparenta utbetalningar samt till att vidareutveckla registret över förmånstagare (e-INAS ). Stödet är ett av de insatser i den svenska portföljen som tydligt kommer att svara mot de effekter som cyklonen IDAI medfört i de centrala delarna av landet. Minst 18 500 hushåll kommer att nås av insatsen, en siffra som kan komma att öka dramatiskt då fler givare kommer in med särskilt stöd till cyklondrabbade områden.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Support during 2019-2022 with a total sum of 75 million SEK to scale-up the national social cash transfer system through a World Bank Multi Donor Trust Fund. Total budget is ca 180 million SEK, and other donors are UK and the Netherlands. Swedish share around 41 percent of total budget. The fund is active since end of 2018.
Focus is on scaling up cash transfers (social cash transfers, child grant, public works salaries) and on increasing the number of beneficiaries. The contribution is expected to strengthen INAS, the agency for social security, assure an efficient and transparent payment system and develop the beneficary registry (e-INAS). The support is one of the contributions that will reply to the negative effects of the cyclone IDAI in the central parts of the country.
At least 18 500 households will be reached by the intervention, a number toat may increase dramatically as more donors are coming in with specific support to mitigate for the effects of the cyclones.

title.narrative: COVID-19 World Bank Trust Fund Cash Transfers

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Support during 2019-2022 with a total sum of 75 million SEK to scale-up the national social cash transfer system through a World Bank Multi Donor Trust Fund. Total budget is ca 180 million SEK, and other donors are UK and the Netherlands. Swedish share around 41 percent of total budget. The fund is active since end of 2018.
Focus is on scaling up cash transfers (social cash transfers, child grant, public works salaries) and on increasing the number of beneficiaries. The contribution is expected to strengthen INAS, the agency for social security, assure an efficient and transparent payment system and develop the beneficary registry (e-INAS). The support is one of the contributions that will reply to the negative effects of the cyclone IDAI in the central parts of the country.
At least 18 500 households will be reached by the intervention, a number toat may increase dramatically as more donors are coming in with specific support to mitigate for the effects of the cyclones.

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Miljön i Asien och Stillahavsområdet påverkas av klimatförändringar, storskaliga utvecklingsprojekt, städers utbredning, föroreningar, avskogning, vattenbrist och överfiske. Människor saknar ofta information om de miljöproblem som påverkar dem, information som skulle göra det möjligt för dem att uttrycka sin oro över negativa miljöeffekter av storskaliga projekt och att öka deras motståndskraft mot klimatpåverkan. Befintlig miljöinformation är ofta svår att förstå för allmänheten och beslutsfattare. Rösterna från de mest utsatta för klimatförändringarnas effekter - kvinnor, ungdomar och inhemska samhällen - marginaliseras och hörs sällan i lokala eller internationella medier. Miljöjournalister och lokala miljöaktivister arbetar ofta isolerat och utan stöd och kan inte koppla in i de större globala samtalen. Dessutom tenderar kommunikationsinfrastrukturen att vara dålig på lokal nivå. Media-folk saknar medel, tid och expertis och står ofta inför dåligt utrustade forskningsinstitut och motstånd från myndigheterna att tillhandahålla öppna data.
Internews Earth Journalism Network (EJN) s övergripande mål är att beslutsfattare, människor och samhällen använder ny kunskap för att utveckla bättre miljöpolicy och planer för naturresurshantering. EJN syftar till att öka kvantiteten och kvaliteten på miljörapportering i Asien-Stillahavsområdet. Tillvägagångssätten omfattar utbildningar, stipendier till större miljötoppmöten, delbidrag, stipendier och utveckling av webb för öppen data. De förväntade resultaten inkluderar: 1) Förbättrad tillförlitlig tillgång för allmänheten, samhällen och beslutsfattare till olika källor till socio-miljöinformation 2) Förbättrad mängd och kvalitet av socio-miljöinformation 3) Ökad inkludering av kvinnor och marginaliserade grupper i socio-miljömedia och information 4) Ökad kunskapsdelning och / eller samverkan kring samhälls-miljöinformation
Outputs inkluderar: - 45 Organisationsbidrag - Tilldelas lokala mediapartners, CSOs, icke-statliga organisationer eller andra gräsrotsgrupper för lokal kapacitetsuppbyggnad, nätverk, innehållsproduktion etc. - 152 Särskilda Projektutmärkelser - Beviljade bidrag till individer / grupper, frilansare, videografer, bloggare, entreprenörer, dataloggare, CSO-grupper, nystartade företag och andra "icke-uttag" -grupper som ansöker om att göra socio-miljöprojekt. - 120 Story Grants - Tilldelas individuella journalister för produktion av nyheter och särdrag. - Utbildning av tränare för 200 journalister - Att bygga lokalt ledarskap och förbättra det regionala nätverket av miljömediapartner, redaktörer, tränare och mentorer - Cirka 4000 praktikanter utbildade för att producera kvalitativ socio-miljöinformation per år - Omkring 1 000 000 publikum träffades globalt per år - Medlemmar av klimatförändringsmedier (CCMP) - utdelas varje år till ett dussin ledande journalister från regionen för att delta i och täcka de årliga klimat toppmötena för FN: s klimatkonvention, vilket gör det möjligt för dem att engagera sig på global nivå och kraftigt bygga upp sin kapacitet - GeoJournalistik - Utveckling och underhåll av regionala webbplatser som är avsedda för miljöskydd av nyckelområden, inklusive användandet av visualiserad data och andra innovativa digitala medietekniker. - Relevanta forskningsprojekt (identifierade under genomförandefasen) Sverige kommer att stödja EJN från 2017-2021, med budgeten 46 801 000 kronor.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The Asia Pacific region is impacted by environmental stress resulting from climate change, large scale development projects, urban excess, pollution, deforestation, water scarcity and overfishing among others. Communities affected often lack information of the environmental challenges they are facing which would allow them to voice their concern over the negative environmental effects of large scale projects as well as to increase their resilience to the impacts of climate change. Existing environmental information is often unintelligible to the public and policy-makers. The voices of those most vulnerable to the effects of climate change – women, youth, and indigenous communities- are marginalised and rarely heard in either local or international media. Environmental journalists and local environmental activists not seldom work in isolation and without support, and may be disconnected from larger global conversations. Moreover, communication infrastructure tends poor at local level. Media workers lack funds, time and expertise and are facing ill-equipped research institutions, or reluctance by authorities to provide open data.
Internews’ Earth Journalism Network (EJN)’s overarching goal is that policy makers, people and communities use new knowledge to develop better environmental policies and natural resource management plans. EJN aims to boost the quantity and quality of environmental media coverage in the Asia-Pacific region. The approaches include training programmes, fellowships to major environmental summits, sub-grants, story stipends, open data webpage development. The expected results includes:
1) Improved reliable access for public, communities, policy makers to diverse sources of socio-environmental information 2) Improved quantity and quality of socio-environmental information 3) Increased inclusion of women and marginalized groups in socio-environmental media and information 4) Increased peer to peer & multi-stakeholder knowledge sharing and/or collaboration around socio-environmental information
The outputs include: - 45 Organizational Grants – Awarded to local media partners, CSOs, NGOs or other grass-roots groups for local capacity-building, networking, content production, etc. - 152 Special Project Awards - grants awarded to individuals/groups, freelancers, videographers, bloggers, entrepreneurs, data journalists, CSOs groups, start-ups and other “non-outlet” groups applying to do socio-environmental projects. - 120 Story Grants – Awarded to individual journalists for production of news and feature pieces. - Training of Trainers for 200 journalists – to build local leadership and enhance the regional network of environmental media partners, editors, trainers and mentors - Around 4,000 trainees trained for producing quality socio-environmental information per year - Around 1,000,000 hits of audience reached globally per year - Climate Change Media Partnership (CCMP) Fellowships – awarded each year to a dozen leading journalists from the region to attend and cover the annual UNFCCC climate summits, enabling them to engage at the global level, and greatly build their capacity - GeoJournalism – Development and Maintenance of regional websites dedicated to environmental coverage of key regions, including the use of visualized data and other innovative digital media techniques. - Relevant research projects (identified during the implementation phase)
Sweden will support EJN from 2017-2021, with the budget as of SEK 46 801 000.

sector.narrative: Media and free flow of information

tag.narrative: 13.3 - Förbättra utbildningen, medvetenheten och den mänskliga och institutionella kapaciteten vad gäller begränsning av klimatförändringarna, klimatanpassning, begränsning av klimatförändringarnas konsekvenser samt tidig varning.
13.3 - Improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning.
14.1 - By 2025, prevent and significantly reduce marine pollution of all kinds, in particular from land-based activities, including marine debris and nutrient pollution.
14.1 - Till 2025 förebygga och avsevärt minska alla slags föroreningar i havet, i synnerhet från landbaserad verksamhet, inklusive marint skräp och tillförsel av näringsämnen.
16.10 - 0 Säkerställa allmän tillgång till information och skydda grundläggande friheter, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning och internationella avtal.
16.10 - Ensure public access to information and protect fundamental freedoms, in accordance with national legislation and international agreements.
6.b - Stödja och stärka lokalsamhällenas deltagande i arbetet med att förbättra vatten- och sanitetshanteringen.
6.b - Support and strengthen the participation of local communities in improving water and sanitation management.

description.narrative: It is assessed that the outcomes of the EJN’s Year 3 implementation were achieved as planned. The quantitative reporting on the number of the audience access to socio-environmental information, media grants, and networks have been progressed as committed in the result-based management framework. However, the qualitative outcome on the inclusion of women and marginalised groups in the content and information remains to be seen. This result will be assessed and reported in the final year of reporting in 2021. The most challenging disruption is the spread of Covid19, resulted in the amendment of core activities, delay of the implementation, and severe risks to overall media landscape. It is assessed that EJN has responded well to uncertainties and needs that come along with the pandemic by using the online platform. Nevertheless, it is admitted that the quality of media capacity building through the virtual one is limited by accessibility of online facilities. Progress against outcomes: Policymakers, communities and global audiences have improved reliable access to diverse sources of socio-environmental information EJN has provided access to environment-related stories which have been read over 1.77 million times (as of 31 August 2020). This project has also distributed 244 stories with a total of 412,312 accumulative page views by Year 3, exceeding the target of 102,242. Media organisations have improved quantity and quality of socio-environmental information EJN has produced a total of 5,372 original stories (with 815 original stories produced in Year 3 alone), surpassing the target of 4,700 – 4,900 accumulated stories by this time. 2,221 journalists (887 females) in environmental reporting were trained. Capacity building and financial support to 19 partners that strengthen environmental reporting were also provided. Media organisations increasingly include women and marginalised groups in socio-environmental content and information EJN is not able to assess progress towards this outcome in Year 3. The content analysis will be done at the end-line of the project in 2021. Journalists, media networks and other environmental actors increasingly collaborate and share knowledge around socio-environmental information The number of networks supported (49 against the target of 36); the number of spaces for multi-stakeholder knowledge sharing facilitated (16 against the target 13); the total number of members using spaces to share and collaborate (64,008 against the target of 33,495) were achieved as planned. A social network analysis will be done in 2021 for improvement. Highlights of qualitative results: Impact at the decision-making level: it is not common to have the evidence-based result on how the media coverage affects the action and practice of the decision-making level. EJN is proven they have the strong M&E capacity to keep track of the behavioural change. One example is environmental pollution that was halted at a Thai landfill thanks to stories produced with project support. The other was how the government in Pakistan decided to legalise a Karachi slum, meaning residents gained the right to legally stay on the land. In the Philippines, in 2019 the media outlet Rappler published an article on the lack of access to water in the south-eastern Albay province of the Philippines. Later, the local government announced plans to allocate up to PHP 200 million (approx. USD $4.1m) for waterless areas. Local politician confirmed in an interview with Rappler that the article motivated the government to act. This change came about as a result of reporting supported by an EJN sub-grant. It is important to note that verifying claims can be a lengthy process, as social and political change takes time. China’s Belt and Road Initiative: A special reporting series on the socio-environmental impact of China’s Belt and Road Initiative are continued to investigate the new pressures China’s Belt and Road Initiative. During this reporting period, the understanding of water tension in Central Asia has increased. Central Asia is one of the world’s most water stressed regions which the hydropower dams have been contructed by the upstream and downstream countries to meet the energy need. China, sitting upstream, is in a powerful position to exploit the region’s water resources. This situation needs to be better understood and paid more attention by policy makers, media and the general public. Covid’s response: EJN has responded well to the Covid situation. The reporting becomes more difficult at a time when journalists’ movements are restricted, and the world’s attention is on a global health crisis. EJN had to postpone their media fellowship program for UN Climate Change COP26 and UN CBD COP 15 to 2021 for both conferences. From this situation, EJN conducted the partners and members’ need assessment during the pandemic. Their need included skills and training for data journalism and investigative reporting; webinars focused on coronavirus and climate change; tools to help fact-check and combat misinformation; tools to report remotely and reach new audiences; financial support; safety tips and psychological support; and access to new research and experts. EJN responded to these needs by tapping resources from Internews’ global program i.e delivery of the Rapid Response Fund for media partners, digital security training. The series of webinars on zoonotic diseases, Covid19 implication on the climate change agenda, wildlife trafficking were provided to build partners’ capacity to understand the issues. The human dimension on Covid consequences to women and marginalised population (i.e migrant workers, indigenous peoples, informal workers, refugees) was also highlighted in the production of Covid storygrants. It is assessed that their responses to the unprecedented Covid crisis are very relevance and meet the need of beneficiaries.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The Asia Pacific region is impacted by environmental stress resulting from climate change, large scale development projects, urban excess, pollution, deforestation, water scarcity and overfishing among others. Communities affected often lack information of the environmental challenges they are facing which would allow them to voice their concern over the negative environmental effects of large scale projects as well as to increase their resilience to the impacts of climate change. Existing environmental information is often unintelligible to the public and policy-makers. The voices of those most vulnerable to the effects of climate change – women, youth, and indigenous communities- are marginalised and rarely heard in either local or international media. Environmental journalists and local environmental activists not seldom work in isolation and without support, and may be disconnected from larger global conversations. Moreover, communication infrastructure tends poor at local level. Media workers lack funds, time and expertise and are facing ill-equipped research institutions, or reluctance by authorities to provide open data.
Internews’ Earth Journalism Network (EJN)’s overarching goal is that policy makers, people and communities use new knowledge to develop better environmental policies and natural resource management plans. EJN aims to boost the quantity and quality of environmental media coverage in the Asia-Pacific region. The approaches include training programmes, fellowships to major environmental summits, sub-grants, story stipends, open data webpage development. The expected results includes:
1) Improved reliable access for public, communities, policy makers to diverse sources of socio-environmental information 2) Improved quantity and quality of socio-environmental information 3) Increased inclusion of women and marginalized groups in socio-environmental media and information 4) Increased peer to peer & multi-stakeholder knowledge sharing and/or collaboration around socio-environmental information
The outputs include: - 45 Organizational Grants – Awarded to local media partners, CSOs, NGOs or other grass-roots groups for local capacity-building, networking, content production, etc. - 152 Special Project Awards - grants awarded to individuals/groups, freelancers, videographers, bloggers, entrepreneurs, data journalists, CSOs groups, start-ups and other “non-outlet” groups applying to do socio-environmental projects. - 120 Story Grants – Awarded to individual journalists for production of news and feature pieces. - Training of Trainers for 200 journalists – to build local leadership and enhance the regional network of environmental media partners, editors, trainers and mentors - Around 4,000 trainees trained for producing quality socio-environmental information per year - Around 1,000,000 hits of audience reached globally per year - Climate Change Media Partnership (CCMP) Fellowships – awarded each year to a dozen leading journalists from the region to attend and cover the annual UNFCCC climate summits, enabling them to engage at the global level, and greatly build their capacity - GeoJournalism – Development and Maintenance of regional websites dedicated to environmental coverage of key regions, including the use of visualized data and other innovative digital media techniques. - Relevant research projects (identified during the implementation phase)
Sweden will support EJN from 2017-2021, with the budget as of SEK 46 801 000.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Miljön i Asien och Stillahavsområdet påverkas av klimatförändringar, storskaliga utvecklingsprojekt, städers utbredning, föroreningar, avskogning, vattenbrist och överfiske. Människor saknar ofta information om de miljöproblem som påverkar dem, information som skulle göra det möjligt för dem att uttrycka sin oro över negativa miljöeffekter av storskaliga projekt och att öka deras motståndskraft mot klimatpåverkan. Befintlig miljöinformation är ofta svår att förstå för allmänheten och beslutsfattare. Rösterna från de mest utsatta för klimatförändringarnas effekter - kvinnor, ungdomar och inhemska samhällen - marginaliseras och hörs sällan i lokala eller internationella medier. Miljöjournalister och lokala miljöaktivister arbetar ofta isolerat och utan stöd och kan inte koppla in i de större globala samtalen. Dessutom tenderar kommunikationsinfrastrukturen att vara dålig på lokal nivå. Media-folk saknar medel, tid och expertis och står ofta inför dåligt utrustade forskningsinstitut och motstånd från myndigheterna att tillhandahålla öppna data.
Internews Earth Journalism Network (EJN) s övergripande mål är att beslutsfattare, människor och samhällen använder ny kunskap för att utveckla bättre miljöpolicy och planer för naturresurshantering. EJN syftar till att öka kvantiteten och kvaliteten på miljörapportering i Asien-Stillahavsområdet. Tillvägagångssätten omfattar utbildningar, stipendier till större miljötoppmöten, delbidrag, stipendier och utveckling av webb för öppen data. De förväntade resultaten inkluderar: 1) Förbättrad tillförlitlig tillgång för allmänheten, samhällen och beslutsfattare till olika källor till socio-miljöinformation 2) Förbättrad mängd och kvalitet av socio-miljöinformation 3) Ökad inkludering av kvinnor och marginaliserade grupper i socio-miljömedia och information 4) Ökad kunskapsdelning och / eller samverkan kring samhälls-miljöinformation
Outputs inkluderar: - 45 Organisationsbidrag - Tilldelas lokala mediapartners, CSOs, icke-statliga organisationer eller andra gräsrotsgrupper för lokal kapacitetsuppbyggnad, nätverk, innehållsproduktion etc. - 152 Särskilda Projektutmärkelser - Beviljade bidrag till individer / grupper, frilansare, videografer, bloggare, entreprenörer, dataloggare, CSO-grupper, nystartade företag och andra "icke-uttag" -grupper som ansöker om att göra socio-miljöprojekt. - 120 Story Grants - Tilldelas individuella journalister för produktion av nyheter och särdrag. - Utbildning av tränare för 200 journalister - Att bygga lokalt ledarskap och förbättra det regionala nätverket av miljömediapartner, redaktörer, tränare och mentorer - Cirka 4000 praktikanter utbildade för att producera kvalitativ socio-miljöinformation per år - Omkring 1 000 000 publikum träffades globalt per år - Medlemmar av klimatförändringsmedier (CCMP) - utdelas varje år till ett dussin ledande journalister från regionen för att delta i och täcka de årliga klimat toppmötena för FN: s klimatkonvention, vilket gör det möjligt för dem att engagera sig på global nivå och kraftigt bygga upp sin kapacitet - GeoJournalistik - Utveckling och underhåll av regionala webbplatser som är avsedda för miljöskydd av nyckelområden, inklusive användandet av visualiserad data och andra innovativa digitala medietekniker. - Relevanta forskningsprojekt (identifierade under genomförandefasen) Sverige kommer att stödja EJN från 2017-2021, med budgeten 46 801 000 kronor.

title.narrative: IOM CREST Ethical Recruitment of Migrant Workers
IOM CREST Etisk rekrytering av migrantarbetare

description.narrative: Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 IOM:s femåriga projekt, "Enhancing Corporate Responsibility in Eliminating Slavery and Trafficking in Asia (CREST Project)", syftar till att förbättra villkoren för migrantarbetare i Asien genom att stärka kapaciteten hos privatsektoraktörer inom leverantörskedjor i Asien att rekrytera och anställa enligt internationella principer för etisk rekrytering. Projektet ämnar förhindra den sårbara situation som framförallt många kvinnor hamnar i genom arbetsmigration, såsom skuldsättning till följd av dyra rekryteringsavgifter, avsaknad av rätt till exempelvis sjukvård i destinationslandet och svaga rättigheter gentemot arbetsgivaren. Då rekryteringsfirmor spelar en viktig roll kommer IOM att särskilt kartlägga och utbilda dessa i syfte att de ska efterleva internationella principer för etisk rekrytering. En av kärnprinciperna är att rekryteringskostnaden ska bäras av det företag som i slutänden anställer och inte av arbetstagaren som migrerar. Internationella företag som köper från asiatiska leverantörer förväntas engageras i projektet och bidra med resurser till att stärka kapaciteten hos sina underleverantörer. Målet är att få till stånd etiskt hållbara rekryteringsprocesser som väntas leda till att migrerande kvinnor och män har större tillgång till säkra rekryteringskanaler där de inte råkar ut för exploatering, kränkningar eller hamnar i ekonomisk skuld när de flyttar för att arbeta på annan ort.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 IOM’s five year project, "Enhancing Corporate Responsibility in Eliminating Slavery and Trafficking in Asia (CREST Project)", aims to improve the conditions for migrant workers in Asia by strengthening the capacity of private sector actors’ value chains in Asia, to recruit and hire in accordance with international praxis for ethical recruitment. The project aims to hinder the vulnerable situation that many women face in labour migration, such as indebtedness due to high recruitment fees, lack of right to healthcare in the country of destination and weak rights in relation to the employer. As the recruitment firms have an important role, IOM will map and train these to adhere to international principles for ethical recruitment. One of the core principles is that the recruitment fee shall be absorbed by the company that in the end employs and not borne by the migrant worker. International companies that source from Asian suppliers are expected to be engaged in the project and contribute with resources to strengthen the capacity of its suppliers. The aim is to establish ethical recruitment practices that are expected to lead to that more migrating women and men have better access to safe recruitment channels and are not exposed to exploitation, violation or indebted when moving to seek work at another destination.

tag.narrative: 10.7 - Facilitate orderly, safe, regular and responsible migration and mobility of people, including through the implementation of planned and well-managed migration policies.
10.7 - Underlätta en ordnad, säker, reglerad och ansvarsfull migration och rörlighet av personer, inklusive genom planerad och väl fungerande migrationspolitik.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.

8.7 - Take immediate and effective measures to eradicate forced labour, end modern slavery and human trafficking and secure the prohibition and elimination of the worst forms of child labour, including recruitment and use of child soldiers, and by 2025 end child labour in all its forms .

8.7 - Vidta omedelbara och effektiva åtgärder för att avskaffa tvångsarbete, modernt slaveri och människohandel och säkra att de värsta formerna av barnarbete, inklusive rekrytering och användning av barnsoldater, förbjuds och upphör. Avskaffa alla former av barnarbete senast 2025.
8.8 - Protect labour rights and promote safe and secure working environments for all workers, including migrant workers, in particular women migrants, and those in precarious employment.

8.8 - Skydda arbetstagarnas rättigheter och främja en trygg och säker arbetsmiljö för alla arbetstagare, inklusive arbetskraftsinvandrare, i synnerhet kvinnliga migranter, och människor i otrygga anställningar.

description.narrative: In the third implementation year, IOM-CREST was affected by the travel restrictions in the context of Covid-19. The IOM-CREST regional team took a pro-active approach in responding to the situation by drawing the findings from the initial analysis of the impacts on migrant workers' rights, conducted in March 2020 by IOM, then adjusting some programme activities that relevant to the need of the migrant workers as well as feasible in the limited mobility context. The programme management team submitted a contingency plan with proposed changes of activities to the Embassy for approval in a timely manner. Based on the contingency plan for year-3, a number of activities were switched to a digital platform. IOM-CREST website was updated to increase its capacity and to enhance a user's experiences. CREST newsletter was distributed more often to update key trends and new guidelines and tools for the employer in protecting the right of migrant workers during the pandemic. Despite the challenging year, IOM-CREST achieved various results which can be summarised as follow. For clarity, the results are groupped into A) Expected results which can be directly linked to the programme inputs; and B) Results in a broader context which can be linked relevant development trend A. Expected results -By the end of the third year of IOM-CREST in September 2020, new partnerships were signed with five companies across three sectors of electronics, retailing and technology. To date, the uptake of private sector partnerships under the CREST project was totalling USD 4,615,580 which is equivalent to 92% of the envisioned target of private sector contribution. -The first cross-border labour supply chain mapping in the palm oil sector in Malaysia, India and Indonesia was commenced. IOM-CREST partners with the Earthworm Foundation to conduct this mapping. - Capacity building: 14 trainings were delivered to 472 employees (293 women, 179 men) of brands and their suppliers on modern slavery and ethical recruitment. The trainings were based on the new CREST training programme, as well as tailored modules that respond to identified gaps or tool roll-out for private sector partners in the context of the partnerships. -12 tools and methodologies were produced and revised. Examples of key guideline include COVID-19 guidance package for businesses and relevant stakeholder to enhance worker protection during the pandemic; Responsible Recruitment Due Diligence Toolkit and Recruitment Agency Due Diligence Checklist; and Benchmarking and gaps analysis methodology to assist company partners in their development and revisions of migrant worker and ethical recruitment policies and procedures -IOM-CREST works closely with the businesses and their suppliers to strengthen human rights due diligence to support the implementation of ethical recruitment and improving access to remedy. A concrete result to highlight from the programme activity in Malaysia - technical inputs and training was provided to a multinational electronics company to develop and adopt a protocol for reimbursement of excessive recruitment fees and costs to the current migrant workforce. In September 2020, the company started the repayment process to the employed migrant workers. The reimbursement to an estimated 3731 is ongoing and expected to be complete by September 2021. Furthermore, IOM CREST is currently working with 4 brands and their suppliers on integrating effective remediation tools and methodologies in line with the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights criteria. -Technical analysis and input were fed into existing and new policies and guidelines of five partner companies with a focus on pertaining the recruitment and employment of migrant workers. -Strategic Partnership with CSOs: On 1 January 2020, the strategic partnership project between IOM and the Migrant Forum in Asia (MFA) was launched. The partnership aims to strengthen the capacity of civil society to engage with the private sector on protection of migrant workers. Due to COVID-19, planned activities were amended and postponed, and a contingency plan was developed to increase the early engagement and progress the activities that deemed feasible under COVID-19 circumstances. The online assessment was shared with 19 organizations in 11 countries reaching more than 80 CSOs in the MFA network. Also, to initiate dialogue and gauge input and best practices for the training programme and Private Sector Engagement Strategy for CSO. MFA and IOM co-organized the first of a series of online events gathering 127 participants (estimated 70 women and 57 men) from civil society organizations, private sector, UN organizations, labour recruiters, industry associations and governments. -Two gender briefs were produced and circulated with CREST partners including Addressing Women Migrant Worker Vulnerabilities in International Supply Chains and Gender info sheet, to improve business understanding on gender dimensions of labour exploitation in the context of labour migration into international business supply chains. Through direct partnerships with multinational enterprises, IOM advocates for a gender-sensitive approach and to incorporate gender-sensitive awareness, questions and solutions to the tools, guidance, and policies that IOM supports the development of. -Communication: 14 issues of the CREST newsletter were distributed during the third project year. The newsletter has seen an almost 30 percent increase in subscribers, particularly following COVID-19, where the CREST team increased to monthly publication of newsletters to accommodate increasing requests from private sector stakeholders to receive relevant COVID-19 updates and tools to support their efforts in protecting migrant workers during the pandemic. Additionally, 22 public references of CREST partnerships with IOM were recorded through newspaper and industry news articles, social media and partner website. -Mid-term Evaluation: the process has started since June 2020 when the TOR was jointly drafted by the CREST team and the Embassy, followed by a call for applications for this assignment. The consulting firm for the assignment was selected based on the expertise and experiences in evaluating various large-scale development projects that have the objective in promoting the rights and well-being of the marginalised groups including migrant workers. At the start of the MTR, the Reference Group, comprised of relevant staff from wider IOM, CREST regional team and Sida, was set up to provide inputs and feedback along the process. The PO and a point of contact for IOM at Sida HQ join the reference group. The data collection was complete and preliminary findings were shared with the reference group mid-January 2021 for comments. It is expected that the final MTE report will be available by March 2021. B. Results in a broader context: upon completion of the third year of IOM-CREST programme, the PO has observed that; -The topic on the protection of migrant workers' right increasingly gains an attention by different actors as a result of the Covid-19. This observation is made with reference to the success of IOM-CREST programme in securing new partnerships with five companies despite the economic downturn. This reflects the need and the interest from the business in continuing their engagement and efforts in the protection of migrant workers' rights. -Good practices on ethical recruitment and labour protection are gradually picked up businesses. At IOM-CREST level, various companies have started to update its policy related to migrant workers in line with technical advice from the CREST team. This progression is line with an emerging global trend of leading corporates (a member of UN Global Compact, RBA, etc.) in their quick responses to uphold the rights of its workforce and suppliers. -Businesses show interest in collective knowledge sharing through their networks. For example in Vietnam, the Networks’ Ethical Recruitment Working Group has been formed for sharing knowledge, identifying solutions to common challenges associated with adopting and implementing ethical recruitment practices. This is also in alignment with a recent trend of the key global business networks such as Shift and International Organisation for Employers (IOE) in its emphasis on Human Rights Due Diligence (HRDD) in their operations. -A profile of IOM-CREST is incrementally increasing amongst a wider group of actors and stakeholders. Although the programme's focus is specific to the collaboration with the private sector, the programme has been also consulted for inputs to the government ministries, policy makers, and other UN agencies in relevant field. For example, the capacity building was provided to SMEs in Malaysia as per the request of Ministry of International Trade and Industries and the technical input was fed into the development National Action Plan on Responsible Business Conduct as per the request of the Vietnamese Government. -IOM-CREST appears to be well-aligned with Business and Human Rights agenda as well as sustainable business dynamics in the region. Given the launch of the NAP by Thailand and Japan as well as the current development of the NAP process in some countries in this region, there is strategic opportunity for the programme to deepen its engagement and leverage its relevance in the region. -Feasible scale-up of CREST intitative in different region(s): The initial discussion at wider IOM divisions identified the possibility of increasing its engagement with private sector on labour supply chain integrity and migrant worker protection. A feasibility study, financed by IOM’s Migration Resource Allocation Committee (MIRAC), an internal funding mechanism, will be conducted to explore and support a more global roll-out of the CREST methodology and tools to contribute to IOM´s wider efforts on pertaining to engagement with the private sector in this aspect. The study will seek to analyse factors determining the feasibility of scaling up the CREST initiative globally.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: IOM CREST Ethical Recruitment of Migrant Workers
IOM CREST Etisk rekrytering av migrantarbetare

description.narrative: Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 IOM:s femåriga projekt, "Enhancing Corporate Responsibility in Eliminating Slavery and Trafficking in Asia (CREST Project)", syftar till att förbättra villkoren för migrantarbetare i Asien genom att stärka kapaciteten hos privatsektoraktörer inom leverantörskedjor i Asien att rekrytera och anställa enligt internationella principer för etisk rekrytering. Projektet ämnar förhindra den sårbara situation som framförallt många kvinnor hamnar i genom arbetsmigration, såsom skuldsättning till följd av dyra rekryteringsavgifter, avsaknad av rätt till exempelvis sjukvård i destinationslandet och svaga rättigheter gentemot arbetsgivaren. Då rekryteringsfirmor spelar en viktig roll kommer IOM att särskilt kartlägga och utbilda dessa i syfte att de ska efterleva internationella principer för etisk rekrytering. En av kärnprinciperna är att rekryteringskostnaden ska bäras av det företag som i slutänden anställer och inte av arbetstagaren som migrerar. Internationella företag som köper från asiatiska leverantörer förväntas engageras i projektet och bidra med resurser till att stärka kapaciteten hos sina underleverantörer. Målet är att få till stånd etiskt hållbara rekryteringsprocesser som väntas leda till att migrerande kvinnor och män har större tillgång till säkra rekryteringskanaler där de inte råkar ut för exploatering, kränkningar eller hamnar i ekonomisk skuld när de flyttar för att arbeta på annan ort.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 IOM’s five year project, "Enhancing Corporate Responsibility in Eliminating Slavery and Trafficking in Asia (CREST Project)", aims to improve the conditions for migrant workers in Asia by strengthening the capacity of private sector actors’ value chains in Asia, to recruit and hire in accordance with international praxis for ethical recruitment. The project aims to hinder the vulnerable situation that many women face in labour migration, such as indebtedness due to high recruitment fees, lack of right to healthcare in the country of destination and weak rights in relation to the employer. As the recruitment firms have an important role, IOM will map and train these to adhere to international principles for ethical recruitment. One of the core principles is that the recruitment fee shall be absorbed by the company that in the end employs and not borne by the migrant worker. International companies that source from Asian suppliers are expected to be engaged in the project and contribute with resources to strengthen the capacity of its suppliers. The aim is to establish ethical recruitment practices that are expected to lead to that more migrating women and men have better access to safe recruitment channels and are not exposed to exploitation, violation or indebted when moving to seek work at another destination.
